module.p:
Generic quantity nouns are common nouns which can be used as the basis of generic quantity expressions, for example –
beagan
few, little, modicum
uiread
as/so much/many, quantity, modicum, number
cus
glut, too much/many, surfeit

Generic quantity nouns can typically be used to quantify both substances (mass nouns) and aggregates (plural nouns) –
mòran airgid a lot of money
grunn bhonn several coins

Generic quantity nouns can also be used in partitive (definite) expressions –
beagan den bhainne a little of the milk
barrachd de na h-ùbhlan more of the apples

section.p: Generic quantity nouns can occur with a few different kinds of grammatical dependent.

When what is being quantified can be inferred from context, the generic quantity noun can occur on its own –
Dh’ith Mairead tòrr. Margaret ate a lot.
Tha tuilleadh aig Iain. John has more.

When what is being quantified is indefinite (usually new to the discourse), it can be expressed as a modifier of the generic quantity noun, either the genitive singular of a mass noun or the genitive plural of a count noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid beagan uisge. Rachel drank a little water.
Tha cus chon aig Màiri. Mary has too many dogs.

When what is being quantified is definite (usually an entity already invoked in the discourse), it can be introduced by the partitive preposition de of governing a specified (definite) noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid beagan den fhìon. Rachel drank a little of the wine.
Cheannaich Màiri cus de mo bhriosgaidean. Mary bought too many of my biscuits.

When what is being quantified is already known, and has just been mentioned, the generic quantity noun can be followed by one of the de prepositional pronouns –
Dh’ith Mairead tòrr dheth. Margaret ate a lot of it.
Tha uiread dhiubh aig Iain! John has so many of them!

Note that phrases like the following, with genitives or possessive pronouns, are not acceptable partitives – beagan an fheòla for a little of the meat (cf. the correct form beagan den fheòil), ar cus for too many of us (cf. the correct forms cus dhinn or cus againn).

Here is a comprehensive thematic list of the generic quantity nouns –
simple
large – mòran
a lot, many, much, tòrr
heap, mass, a lot, an t-uabhas
enormity, great quantity, awful lot
small – beagan
few, little, modicum, deannan
pinch, puckle
middling/neutral – cuid
measure, part, portion, grunn
batch, group, number
comparative
larger – barrachd
more, predominance, preponderance, tuilleadh
more, extra
equal – uimhir / uiread
as/so much/many, quantity, modicum, number
smaller – nas lugha fewer, less
indirectly comparative
excessive – anabarr
excess, redundancy, superfluity, cus
glut, too much/many, surfeit
sufficient – leòr
satiety, sufficiency, enough, plenty, neart
plenty, abundance, pailteas
abundance, plenty
insufficient – ro bheag too little, too few
